did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.origination: American Dance Festival, John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Thirteen/WNET New York
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the ADF Archives.
did.abstract: Free to Dance: The African-American Presence in Modern Dance was a three-part television documentary co-produced by the American Dance Festival and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in association with Thirteen/WNET New York. The series aired on PBS' Great Performances: Dance in America in 2001. It chronicled the role of African-American choreographers and dancers in the development of modern dance as an American art form.

The collection includes film, video, sound recordings, oral histories, interview transcripts, business records, photographs, clippings, and research materials created or collected during the production of the three-part television documentary Free to Dance.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Patrons must sign the Acknowledgement of Legal Responsibility and Privacy Rights form before using this collection.
In off-site storage; 48 hours advance notice is required for use.

Access to film, videotapes, or audiotapes in this collection requires the use of reference copies. To arrange for the creation of reference copies, if none exist, please contact American Dance Festival Archives.
Records, such as search committee files or others pertaining to employment where individuals are identified, are closed for 70 years.
Portions of these materials are restricted by donor request.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for official American Dance Festival administrative records is held by the American Dance Festival; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Free to Dance Records, American Dance Festival Archives.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Free to Dance Records were received by the American Dance Festival Archives as transfers in 2000-2004.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by ADF Archives Staff, Oct. 2004
Accessions were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Free to Dance: The African-American Presence in Modern Dance was a three-part television documentary co-produced by the American Dance Festival and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in association with Thirteen/WNET New York. The series aired on PBS' Great Performances: Dance in America in 2001 and won an Emmy for Outstanding Cultural and Artistic Programming-Long Form. It chronicled the role of African-American choreographers and dancers in the development of modern dance as an American art form. Dance masterpieces by African-American choreographers were filmed expressly for the series, including the works of Katherine Dunham (Barrelhouse Blues), Pearl Primus (Strange Fruit), Donald McKayle (Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder), Talley Beatty (Mourner's Bench), Bill T. Jones (D-Man in the Waters), Alvin Ailey (Revelations), and many others.

Free to Dance was an outgrowth of the American Dance Festival's Black Tradition in American Modern Dance (BTAMD) program. Initiated in 1987 to preserve, present, and interpret significant dances by African-American choreographers, BTAMD reconstructed and presented twenty-three dances in danger of being lost. BTAMD's national touring initiative presented performances throughout the US by African-American dance companies, including Chuck Davis' African American Dance Ensemble, Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, Philadanco, and Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble. Scholars touring with the companies contextualized and interpreted the cultural and aesthetic significance of the dances in panel discussions.

The success of the BTAMD project led to the creation of Free to Dance, and the American Dance Festival began fund raising efforts in 1993. Fund raising, research, and conceptual development continued through 1997. Full production commenced in 1998, including scripting, securing the rights to archival footage and photos, and the filming of interviews, performances, and scene recreations. Editing was completed in 2001.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection includes business records, grant proposals, correspondence, film, video, sound recordings, oral histories, interview transcripts, photographs, clippings, and research materials created or collected during the production of the three-part television documentary Free to Dance.

The bulk of the Free to Dance Collection dates from 1998 to 2001, when technical production of the series took place; however, the collection also includes grant proposals and early project development documentation dating back to 1987, as well as some correspondence and financial information created after its air date in 2001.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

arrangement.p: Arranged into six subseries: General Administration, Personnel, Finance, Grants and Fund Raising, Licensing and Agreements, and Promotion.

scopecontent.p: Contains information pertaining to office management, including general policies and procedures, equipment purchases and rentals, and staff contact information.
RESTRICTED. Contains salary negotiations, contracts, and employment dates, as well as memoranda and notes regarding employees and their assignments and schedules.
Contains financial records created by the American Dance Festival's Director of the Finance and Administration during the production of Free to Dance.

Contains check requests, invoices, receipts, and correspondence regarding archival repositories, rental facilities, FTD staff, consultants, film crews, and other service providers. The Accounts Payable series also contains signed licensing agreements for the use of footage and music.

did.unittitle: Museum of the City of New York, 1999-2000
New York Public Library Dance Collection Film Fund, 1999-2000

scopecontent.p: Work Orders were used in the early research phase by the archival producers and researchers to account for footage transfers and licensing fees.

did.unittitle: Budgets, Drafts: Film Shoots, Personnel, Show Four, "School," 1995-1999

scopecontent.p: Includes grant proposals, critiques, correspondence, budgets, and other financial information pertaining to the eight major funders of Free to Dance: the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the Ford Foundation, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the National Black Programming Consortium, the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Public Broadcasting Service and its local New York affiliate Thirteen WNET, which replaced WETA (Washington, DC). This subseries also contains information pertaining to other fund raising efforts, especially in relation to international distribution rights and solicitations for outreach and education funding.

Contains documents regarding the reproduction rights for original and archival materials. Related material can also be found in the Licensing Expenses folders under Financial Reports in the Finance Subseries.

Footage agreements were either materials options, which guaranteed the right to use certain clips at a pre-determined price, or fully executed licenses, which were executed after footage was selected for use.

arrangement.p: Materials options are arranged alphabetically by licensor in the first three folders. Final licensing agreements are arranged by show in the last three folders.
Arranged into three subseries: Pre-Production Files, Production Files, and Post-Production Files.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence and documents produced by Gerald E. Myers, the director of ADF's humanities programs, and the team of scholars he gathered to advise the writers and producers. Also includes scheduling and planning memos, treatments, outlines, drafts of scripts, secondary sources research files, and production management records.
Contains notes, correspondence, memoranda, and drafts of interview questions.

did.unittitle: Updates from Series Producer to Executive Producers, 1997-2001

scopecontent.p: RESTRICTED: This material consists of copies of material from other repositories and is not open for research. Contains photocopies of programs, clippings, photographs, magazine articles, book excerpts, books, dissertations, interview transcripts, correspondence, press kits, and related materials used as secondary sources on dance, dancers, choreographers, and twentieth-century history.

scopecontent.p: Contains records created during the production of original footage shot specifically for Free to Dance and the gathering of archival resources used in the completed program.

Includes the production records from the filming of interviews and dances shot specifically for inclusion in Free to Dance, including production itineraries, travel arrangements, camera and sound reports, information on film and lighting equipment, receipts, budgets, invoices, and correspondence with film crews and interviewees.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by the date of each film shoot.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, licensing negotiations, and other materials regarding film, video, sound recordings, photographs, and other documents considered for inclusion in Free to Dance. These materials were compiled by research staff Jenna Lambie, Prudence Arndt, Lewanne Jones, and, occasionally, interns Jada Shapiro and Rachelle Michaud. Several freelance researchers were also employed, two working in Washington, DC, and two in Europe.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by archival repository, stock house, library, or individual owner.

scopecontent.p: Original elements for Free to Dance exist on film, Beta SP, VHS, DVD, DAT, DA-88, audiocassettes, and open reel audio tape. To cross reference elements, see the entries below. Titles and item numbers are taken from hand-written labels on the Beta SP tapes made at film transfer. DVDs or VHS copies of the Betas have the same item number.
Audiocassette copies of the sound reels are numbered, but their numbers are not the same as the sound reels. UB numbers were assigned by DuArt Film & Video during editing.
Additional tapes (without item numbers) are also in the collection. See the box list below.

Five 7" reels of 1/4" audiotape, Sound Rolls 34-38

scopecontent.p: The following tapes appear to contain edited footage of complete versions of individual works. No complete works appear in Free to Dance; however, complete versions of Awassa Astrige/Ostrich, Barrelhouse Blues (excerpt), Strange Fruit, Mourner's Bench, Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder, and D-Man in the Waters (Section 1) are available on Dancing in the Light, a DVD commercially released in 2007.

did.unittitle: Barrelhouse Blues, Choreography by Katherine Dunham, Performance by Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble, TRT 6:30
Children of the Passage (excerpts), Choreography by Donald McKayle and Ron Brown, Performance by Dayton Contemporary Dance Company
D-Man in the Waters, Performance by Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, TRT 14:14
Mourner's Bench, Choreography by Talley Beatty, Performed by Jerome Stigler
Ostrich Dance, Choreography by Asadata Dafora, Performed by Garry Harris
Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder, Choreography by Donald McKayle, Performance by Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, TRT 17:38
The Stack-Up, Choreography by Talley Beatty, Performed by Dayton Contemporary Dance Company
RESTRICTED. Screeners and other copies of video received from various repositories.
